z:row.ows_Title: Experimental Study to Characterize the Performance of Combined Photovoltaic/Thermal Air Collectors
z:row.ows_Plain_x0020_Language_x0020_Summa: This paper presents an experimental method to obtain the electrical and thermal performance of combined photovoltaic/thermal solar collectors using air as the heat transfer fluid. These collectors have the particularity of producing both thermal and electrical energy simultaneously and present great potential to supply part of buildings’ energy requirements. The research presented could be very useful for national and international standards organizations that plan on developing performance standards for combined photovoltaic/thermal solar collectors. The adoption of standardized methods to characterize the performance of such collectors is critical to the acceptance of this technology by both manufacturers and consumers. At the moment, manufacturers are free to use any method to obtain and present the performance of their products and it is difficult for consumers to compare the performance of the products offered and to have confidence in the claimed performance. There are other drawbacks to the market adoption of this technology such as the lack of reliability standards, the low thermal efficiency and the absence of financing schemes and dedicated subsidies. Regulations relative to the methods employed to obtain and present the performance of these collectors would help giving credibility to any actions undertaken to solve these other issues.
z:row.ows_Policy_x0020_Relevance: None of the following apply, Regulations, International Commitments, National or Interprovincial Commitments
z:row.ows_Science_x0020_Policy_x0020_Impli: The results from this paper could be used as a basis for develoing standardized methods to characterize the thermal and electrical performance of combined phototovoltaic/ thermal solar collectors.
z:row.ows_LinkTitleNoMenu: Experimental Study to Characterize the Performance of Combined Photovoltaic/Thermal Air Collectors
z:row.ows_LinkTitle: Experimental Study to Characterize the Performance of Combined Photovoltaic/Thermal Air Collectors

z:row.ows_Title: A Compliance-Based Module for Supporting Government Energy Programs, Codes and Regulations
z:row.ows_Plain_x0020_Language_x0020_Summa: Energy Codes or other mandatory or incentive-based energy programs for houses and buildings will typically require that a jurisdictional authority sign off on the fact that the house or building is compliant with that Code or energy program. Determining whether or not it is compliant may be straightforward as in the case of prescriptive requirements of the Code ("do this, do that, etc. and it will be deemed compliant"). But it can also be more complex as with performance requirements of the Code where designer is given much more flexibility for their design. In these cases energy simulation of the house or building is employed to help determine compliance. Just like a flight simulator helps train the pilot, so does energy simulation help inform the designer, engineer or architect on how the house or building uses energy. HOT3000 is one such energy simulation tool for houses which has been developed at CanmetENERGY. As HOT3000 is picked up by multiple jurisdictions within Canada to support their local Codes and energy programs, we have developed an approach that will give these jurisdictions maximum flexibility to customize the tool to their needs. We call this the compliance-based module of HOT3000 and is the topic of this publication.
z:row.ows_LinkTitleNoMenu: A Compliance-Based Module for Supporting Government Energy Programs, Codes and Regulations
z:row.ows_LinkTitle: A Compliance-Based Module for Supporting Government Energy Programs, Codes and Regulations

z:row.ows_Title: Modelling the Power Production of a Photovoltaic System: Comparison of Sugeno-Type Fuzzy Logic and PVSAT-2 Models
z:row.ows_Plain_x0020_Language_x0020_Summa: This paper compares the performance of models of a photovoltaic (PV) system that converts solar light into electricity. The models use solar irradiance in the array plane and back-of-module temperature in order to predict alternating current (AC) power production. Two methods were used to develop the models: a fuzzy logic-based method, which is a type of artificial intelligence method, and a parametric method that uses equations and adjustable parameters. Different operating regimes of the PV system were established according to different values of the solar irradiance. Models were developed for each of those regimes, as well as global models that use all irradiance values. It is shown that the fuzzy logic model outperforms the parametric model when sufficient amounts of modelling data are available. Meanwhile, the models developed over different irradiance regimes and global models over all irradiance values displayed the same accuracy. The effect of the fuzzy logic model complexity on the predictive accuracy, as well as the effect of the modelling dataset size on the performance of both methods was studied. The results indicate that the models have relatively good prediction accuracy when trained on a small dataset (1 month), and that the parametric method is more robust to accommodating observations that are outside the training dataspace. The models developed will form the basis of a fault detection and diagnosis system for PV systems.
z:row.ows_LinkTitleNoMenu: Modelling the Power Production of a Photovoltaic System: Comparison of Sugeno-Type Fuzzy Logic and PVSAT-2 Models
z:row.ows_LinkTitle: Modelling the Power Production of a Photovoltaic System: Comparison of Sugeno-Type Fuzzy Logic and PVSAT-2 Models

z:row.ows_Title: CFD study on hydrodynamics in three-phase fluidized beds—application of turbulence models and experimental validation
z:row.ows_Plain_x0020_Language_x0020_Summa: Under the Government of Canada’s Clean Energy Fund Program, this study aims to simulate the flow behaviour of gases, liquids and solids during the hydro-conversion process of bitumen upgrading using mathematical models.  The models simulate the concentration, flow direction and velocity of the three materials (air, water and glass beads) in a hydro-conversion reactor.  The results were compared to other published data measured with a similar reactor, verifying that the models can accurately predict the flow behaviour during the hydro-conversion process.
z:row.ows_Science_x0020_Policy_x0020_Impli: This research is to enhances our understanding of the interaction between gases, liquids and solids during the hydro-conversion process of bitumen upgrading.  In doing so, this research contributes to the optimization of this process, potentially improving the environmental and economic performance associated with this aspect of bitumen upgrading.
z:row.ows_LinkTitleNoMenu: CFD study on hydrodynamics in three-phase fluidized beds—application of turbulence models and experimental validation
z:row.ows_LinkTitle: CFD study on hydrodynamics in three-phase fluidized beds—application of turbulence models and experimental validation

z:row.ows_Title: Influence of Blending Vegetable Oil into HVGO on Hydrotreating/Mild Hydrocracking Performance
z:row.ows_Plain_x0020_Language_x0020_Summa: Research at CanmetENERGY is investigating the impacts and benefits of processing biomass derived feedstocks with petroleum feeds (including Canadian bitumen and heavy oils). This work was aimed at understanding the process performance of co-processing biomass derived and petroleum based feedstocks using conventional refining technologies.  The feedstocks were blends of different portions of canola oil and heavy gas oil (HGO) derived from bitumen. A series of experiments were conducted under typical commercial conditions to investigate the effects of adding canola oil into HGO on sulphur and nitrogen removal, and on the diesel product yield and quality. The experimental results demonstrated that the addition of canola oil resulted in higher diesel product yield and quality while the sulphur and nitrogen removal was not affected. In other words, to produce similar amount of diesel, co-processing canola oil with HGO required lower reaction temperature and pressure, effectively reducing related energy consumption and GHG emission.
z:row.ows_Policy_x0020_Relevance: None of the following apply, Public Concern
z:row.ows_Science_x0020_Policy_x0020_Impli: Reducing the carbon footprints or GHG emission is a major challenge during the production and processing of Canadian oil sands bitumen for clean transportation fuels. Co-processing biomass and bitumen derived feeds may provide an alternative solution since the GHG emission for producing renewable biofuels is considered to be significantly lower than that for fossil fuels. In many developed countries, it is required that biofuels replace from 6% to up to 10% of petroleum fuels in the near future. Co-processing biomass and bitumen feeds can use existing refining infrastructure and technologies, saving capital and operation costs. In addition co-processing may generate synergy to improve gasoline and diesel qualities. The research results demonstrated that co-processing canola oil with bitumen could result in reduced process severity while retaining similar product yield and quality, leading to energy and GHG savings.
z:row.ows_LinkTitleNoMenu: Influence of Blending Vegetable Oil into HVGO on Hydrotreating/Mild Hydrocracking Performance
z:row.ows_LinkTitle: Influence of Blending Vegetable Oil into HVGO on Hydrotreating/Mild Hydrocracking Performance

z:row.ows_Title: Numerical Modeling and Experimentation on Evaporator Coils for Refrigeration in Dry and Frosting Operational Conditions, Two Phase Flow, Phase Change and Numerical Modeling
z:row.ows_Retomb_x00e9_es: Confirmation of the numerical model and additional characterization of the heat exchangers using CO2 as the refrigerant could lead to further private sector research/development; the ultimate goal being improved overall refrigeration system energy efficiency and/or reduced cost per unit of cooling capacity.
z:row.ows_Citation: Zine Aidoun, Mohamed Ouzzane and Adlane Bendaoud (2011). Numerical Modeling and Experimentation on Evaporator Coils for Refrigeration in Dry and Frosting Operational Conditions, Two Phase Flow, Phase Change and Numerical Modeling, Amimul Ahsan (Ed.), ISBN

z:row.ows_LinkTitle: Numerical Modeling and Experimentation on Evaporator Coils for Refrigeration in Dry and Frosting Operational Conditions, Two Phase Flow, Phase Change and Numerical Modeling
